marketNews.title: Important Developments During Lebaran Holiday
marketNews.content:
During the Idulfitri 2024 holiday period, several developments need investors' attention:

1. US inflation again exceeds expectations – the US recorded inflation of 3.5% year-on-year in March 2024 (versus February 2024: 3.2%), surpassing the consensus level of 3.4%. This marks the third consecutive month since January 2024 where US inflation data came in higher than expected, reinforcing the “higher for longer rates” narrative. According to analysis from the CME FedWatch Tool, the market now expects the Federal Reserve to start cutting interest rates in the third quarter of 2024, later than the previous expectation of a June 2024 rate cut. Implications of the US inflation development on Tuesday (16/4):
- The yield on the 10-year US Treasury rose from around 4.2% at the end of March 2024 to about 4.6%.
- The US Dollar Index (DXY) increased from level 104 at the end of March 2024 to around 106.
- The S&P 500 index fell 3.7% month-to-date.
- For Indonesia, the negative impact is visible in the rupiah’s depreciation against the US dollar, weakening from 15,880 at the end of March 2024 to 16,176.

2. Escalating geopolitical tension – on 13 April 2024, Iran launched an attack on Israel. This escalation is pushing up the prices of several commodities, such as crude oil, gold, and silver.

3. Commodity price increases due to supply issues and/or better demand outlook – in addition to geopolitical tension, several commodities have strengthened because of supply constraints and improved demand prospects.
- Crude oil: Driven by expectations of a global oil deficit in 2024 as OPEC+ production cuts tighten supply, and higher demand forecasts from stronger-than-expected US and China economic data.
- Tin: Supported by reduced supply uncertainty from Indonesia and Myanmar exports, better manufacturing activity in the US and China, and the ban on Russian metal mining production for trading on the London Metal Exchange.
- Copper: Potential shortage due to the closure of one of the world’s largest copper mines, the Cobre mine in Panama, together with increased demand for copper in the energy transition.
- Nickel: The US and the United Kingdom have imposed trade bans on Russian commodities, including nickel, copper and aluminium, increasing price volatility.
- Pulp: Supply disruptions from Finnish producers following port demonstrations since early March 2024.

Key Takeaway
The series of negative sentiments above caused the Jakarta Composite Index (IHSG) to weaken by 1.68% on Tuesday (16/4), with interest-rate-sensitive sectors such as property (-3.25%), technology (-2.85%) and financials (-2.49%) falling sharply.

However, we consider this correction could be an opportunity for investors to buy banking stocks at more attractive valuations, because, in our view, their fundamentals and prospects remain solid.

Meanwhile, the upward trend in commodity prices and the stronger US dollar could have a positive impact on commodity-related issuers.

- Gaikindo reported wholesale car sales in Indonesia in March 2024 amounted to 74,724 units (+5.8% month-on-month, –26.2% year-on-year). Over the first three months of 2024, wholesale car sales reached only 214,997 units (-23.9% year-on-year), representing 19.5% of the 2024 target of 1.1 million units.
- The Indonesian Motorcycle Industry Association (AISI) recorded domestic motorcycle sales in March 2024 of 583,747 units (+4.5% month-on-month, –7.8% year-on-year). Over the first three months of 2024, domestic motorcycle sales totaled 1.74 million units (-4.9% year-on-year), accounting for 26.7-28% of the 2024 target of 6.2-6.5 million units.
- China’s gross domestic product grew 5.3% year-on-year and 1.6% quarter-on-quarter in 1Q24 (versus 4Q23: 5.2% year-on-year, 1% quarter-on-quarter), beating consensus expectations of 4.6% year-on-year and 1.4% quarter-on-quarter.
- The governments of the United Kingdom and the United States have banned Russian-origin nickel from being traded on the London Metal Exchange and the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. The ban applies to nickel produced after 13 April 2024 and aims to reduce export revenues for Russia amid the war in Ukraine that has been ongoing since 2022. Russia contributes about 6% of global refined nickel production.
- Commodity-analysis firm Kpler reported that China imported 97.43 million tonnes of coal (+16.9% year-on-year) in 1Q24. This surge occurred while consensus forecasts expected China’s coal imports in 2024 to be flat at 450-500 million tonnes (versus 2023 actual 474.42 million tonnes).

tickerNews.title: ADRO Plans Share Buyback Up to IDR 4 Trillion
tickerNews.content: ADRO Energy Indonesia plans a share buyback with a maximum fund of IDR 4 trillion. The maximum amount and price of the buyback have not been announced. The corporate action will run for 12 months starting 16 May 2024. The plan will be discussed at the Extraordinary General Meeting of Shareholders on 15 May 2024.

tickerNews.title: MBMA Secures USD 490 Million Loan Facility for HPAL Smelter
tickerNews.content: Merdeka Battery Materials, through its subsidiary PT ESG New Energy Material, obtained a loan facility of USD 490 million from Bangkok Bank Public Company Limited, Bank Mandiri and Bank Negara Indonesia (BBNI). The facility is intended to finance the construction of an HPAL smelter and to take an equity stake in a feed preparation plant.

tickerNews.title: WINS Wins USD 75 Million Contract for 2M24
tickerNews.content: Wintermar Offshore Marine’s Investor Relations, Pek Swan Layanto, said the company secured a contract worth USD 75 million for the period 2M24. Pek Swan also mentioned that WINS has obtained contracts from India, Brunei Darussalam and Thailand with more favorable rental rates. WINS is preparing two platform supply vessels to start operating in the second half of 2024.

tickerNews.title: AVIA Plans 8-9 New Distribution Centers in 2024
tickerNews.content: Avia Avian’s Head of Investor Relations, Andreas Timothy Hadikrisno, said the company plans to open 8-9 new distribution centers in 2024, at a cost of IDR 2 billion per unit. This capex is in addition to the IDR 450 billion capital expenditure allocated for the continuation of the paint plant construction in Cirebon, West Java. By the end of 2023, AVIA operated 118 own distribution centers, 14 mini-centers and 40 third-party centers. AVIA targets 140 distribution centers by 2026.

tickerNews.title: AKRA Controlling Shareholder Increases Stake to 60.99%
tickerNews.content: The controlling shareholder of AKR Corporindo, PT Arthakencana Rayatama, purchased 2 million shares of AKRA at an average price of IDR 1,733 per share on 5 April 2024. The total transaction value was approximately IDR 3.5 billion. After this transaction, PT Arthakencana Rayatama’s ownership in AKRA increased from 60.98% to 60.99%.
